name: ジュエリー アントワープ (Jewelry Antwerp)
description:
User summary
ジュエリー アントワープ (Jewelry Antwerp) (Juerii Antowaapu) is a Japanese game in which you conduct auctions as Belgian jewel merchants.

Player order for each round is determined by a blind auction using each player’s supply of coin cards, then the cards that were used in the auction are exchanged between players.

In a four-player game the players who won the first and fourth positions in turn order would exchange their cards and the second and third players would exchange theirs. Thus those who have placed lower bids will have more coin cards to use in later rounds.

The first player begins by taking one of the available face-up jewelry cards and can either spend it to earn victory points or save it in their hand to use in combination with other cards in a later round. A maximum of two cards can be saved in hand between rounds.

Once each player has taken their turn, the round ends and the process repeats. When the jewelry card pool is being refilled at the beginning of each round and a beer card is revealed, new rules go into effect and continue until the next beer card is drawn.

Note: the game box closely resembles classic Japanese chocolate box, giving the game a strong retro feel for Japanese players.

Publisher's summary
ベルギーの宝石商となり宝石のオークションをするゲームです。

コインカードを使った、ブラインドオークションでそのラウンドでのプレイ順を決めます。その後でオークションに使用したコインカードをプレイヤー間で交換します。１位と４位が交換し、２位と３位が交換します（４人プレイ時）。

１位のプレイヤーから手番を行います。手番では場に残っている宝石カードを1枚獲得し、宝石カードを消費して勝利点を得ることができます。消費せずに次のラウンドへ、最大で２枚まで残すことができます。

全員が手番を行ったら次のラウンドになります、宝石カードの補充の際にビールが描かれているカードが出たら、次のビールが出るまでの間、ルールに少し変更があります。

name: Dive Dive Dive!
description:
A co-operative game for 1 to 4 players. Each player is a key officer on a U-Boat with an associated special action.

Each turn cards are drawn (one at a time) and placed in numbered spaces along an operations track at the top of a board. The crew commander then rolls two die and refers to the card in the space than number represents. If the card does not relate to the current action state of the U-boat. Nothing happens and play proceeds to the next turn and action state.

If the card mentions the current action state, it's instructions are followed.

The goal is to survive four missions of differing difficulty without loosing a crew member or the U-boat.

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Fairy Queen
description:
This pretty game is fun to play and introduces skip counting, the concept behind multiplication. Players learn to count by twos and by fives as they tally the points they collect to win.

The entire deck is dealt out evenly to each player. Players then take turns drawing a random card from the player to their left when it is their turn trying to get and play matching pairs. Once all matching cards have been played, the player holding the remaining fairy queen card (which doesn't have a match) adds that card to their matches. All players then add up the points shown on their cards, and the player with the most points is the winner.

Contents: 48 playing cards (3.25 x 4.5 inches) and instructions

name: The Red Dragon Inn: 2019 SlugCrew Minor Reward
description:
Publisher's Description:

We have three brand new promo drinks for 2019’s SlugCrew Minor Reward. Oozing with new mechanics introduced by RDI7 and [its character] The Wench, we have two new Elixirs, potent drinks with persistent effects and another brew from one of Chronos’s timelines. To play with promo drinks, just shuffle a few into your normal Drink Deck.

You can earn these drinks by getting 30 SlugCrew points (or about 6 hours worth of demoing). SlugCrew who earn 150 points or more will get our Major Reward, a brand new pre-release character deck: Piper, the Eagle-Eyed Sniper!

Adds 3 drinks to the drink deck:

Backup Brew
Elixir of Alertness
Elixir of Exposure
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Humor

name: Décollage!
description:
Décollage! is a cooperative card game for 1-6 players. You and your team will have to build rocket launchers to put a maximum of satellites in orbit. You will have to avoid inopportune events and minimize risk on launch day.

Players have to manage their hand of cards to collectively assemble launchers and choose which satellite is more appropriate to launch which satellite. Inopportune events can happen during the launching phase, but players have the opportunity to avoid those events by playing event cards. Satellite launch can succeed or fail and the results of all launches will determine if the players win or lose the game.

Décollage! is produced and published by CNES (Centre national d’études spatiales), a French division of ESA (European Space Agency).

—user summary

name: Monopolization
description:
Players take the role of farmers in Wisconsin after the industrial revolution that are expanding into new areas of the business world.

REAL ESTATE
Players travel around Wisconsin and purchase and sell real estate for their companies. Each type of property has a different purpose. They are: railroads, shops, inns, banks, forests, mines, farms, factories, and harbours.

PRICE MANAGEMENT
Presidents of companies can adjust the prices at their properties that may be utilized by other players. They may sell low to attract business or undersell competition, or sell high if they have a monopoly in a particular business.

TRAVELLING
Players try to avoid shops and inns that are too expensive while on their business trips, and visit other cities using the railroad, again trying to avoid overpriced trips.

ANTITRUST LEGISLATION
Players can also visit the capital building in Madison in an attempt to set legal limits on prices in certain industries.

SHARE TRADING AND TAKEOVERS
Presidents of companies can buy and sell shares of stock of other players' companies. This can be done for profit or to attempt a company takeover.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Investment, Network and Route Building, Ownership, Stock Holding, Voting

name: UCF (fan expansion for Formula D)
description:
This is a fan-made track for the Formula D board game, featuring two alternate routes on and around the UCF campus.

It was created as a gift for a friend of mine, Stephen Eckman.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Think It Up! Pictures
description:
What do you see in the picture? A wolf or a dog? A beast or a pet? Would you call a rundown building a hut or a cabin? Or, maybe, a shack? In this game, all your answers are correct and victorious as long as you are fast enough.

Think It Up! Pictures is a great game both for a party and for a family gathering. Each round, you draw two cards: one from the theme deck and one from the picture deck. Your aim is to be the first to come up with a word for the object in the picture, then use its first letter to recall the right word for the theme. The themes are created in such a way that they would be understood by a child, and you don't have to be the most erudite — just the most quick-witted!
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Trivia, Word Game

name: メテオ回収株式会社 (Meteo Inc)
description:
In メテオ回収株式会社 (Meteor Recovery Co., Ltd.), each player controls a robot that roams an asteroid mining the meteors that hit it. Players take 2 actions per turn, and can walk 2 spaces, acquire a technology card, "reboot" their robot if it has fallen, or acquire ore from a meteor dice. Players can also pay for additional special actions with ore they have collected. Once a meteor has been acquired, the die hits the asteroid again by the player dropping it from a height of at least 16cm. The first player to obtain a certain amount of the large yellow ore, depending upon player count, wins.

—user summary
mechanics: Action Points, Pick-up and Deliver, Take That

name: Jungle Rummy
description:
Jungle Rummy is a casual card game for 2-4 people, which takes elements of Hearts, Rummy, and Uno, and transforms them with a Jungle themed twist. The scoring system creates a set of constantly changing objectives, and the interaction between players can be frenzied and passionate.

—user summary

name: Outer Space
description:
Simple roll and move space game where players travel though the solar system. Starting at the sun players maybe assisted on their journey by landing on the planets. Players may also advance or be sent back to planets by landing on specific spots. The first to reach Pluto is the winner. Although not dated, the graphics suggest the game was published around the late 50s to early 60s.

—user summary

name: Risk: Call of Duty Zombies
description:
The legendary zombie demolition crew is back in a classic game of strategic conquest. This custom RISK edition features factions led by "Tank” Dempsey, Edward Richtofen, Takeo Masaki, and Nikolai Belinski as they vie for control over familiar maps. Use Pack-a-Punch cards to gain an advantage against opponents and fend off wave after wave of zombie threats. Experience one of the first Call of Duty table top games that combine the legendary atmosphere of the license with the strategic competition of RISK.

—description from the publisher
categories: Dice, Horror, Video Game Theme, Zombies

name: The Potion Maker
description:
You are the King's Master potion maker, but he's getting frustrated with your lack of progress in creating a special giant strength potion for his army. So, you’ve been commissioned by the King to create the magic potion or else. If you are unable to create the potion for the King, it's off to the dungeon with you! You know that it takes a lot of gold to purchase the special ingredients needed for the magic potion. Each potion you create will be valued in gold pieces and if you can create and sell enough potions to earn a total of 220 gold pieces, you will have enough gold to buy the special ingredients you need to create the magic potion. There are six potion types you can create and sell to other kingdoms across the land. As your workers travel the land, they will collect potion ingredients that you can mix together to create any of the six potions. These potions can then be taken to nearby kingdoms and sold for gold. You can also use your workers to help in the potion creation process.

Victory conditions
Sell enough potions in 15 turns to earn a total of 220 gp or greater giving you enough gold to purchase the required ingredients needed to create the magic potion for the King.

Losing conditions
Fail to earn 220 gp within the 15 turns needed and go directly to the King's dungeon, causing you to lose the game.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement

name: Hotel Transylania 3
description: A children's spin/roll and move game based on the Hotel Transylvania franchise. You play as one of the characters from the film and are running around a cruise ship collecting various travel accessories.
categories: Children's Game, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Rhyme Time
description:
Gameplay in Rhyme Time is simple. Turn six cards from the deck face up so that all players can see the 24 pictures of simple objects on these cards. At the same time, all players start looking for objects whose names rhyme with one another, such as shampoo – kangaroo or doll – ball. Everybody is trying to be the first one to find a pair that rhymes, and the first one to do so claims the two cards showing the rhyming objects and places these cards in their victory pile. Someone then reveals two more cards, and the game continues.

Once all the cards from the deck have been used, and no one can discover more rhyming pairs, the game ends and whoever has collected the most cards wins.

name: Placing the Past
description: The game of time and risk. Play your hand of dates in the correct order to gain points. Use the challenge bell to steal another player's timeline and gain bonus points.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Trivia

name: Number One
description:
Number One is a hand-shedding game along the lines of UNO and Mau Mau. Each player starts with a hand of seven cards, with one card face up in the discard pile. On a turn, you must play a card that matches the color or number of the top card of the discard pile or else play a black action card; alternatively, you can choose to draw a card and if that card is playable, you may do so immediately.

Each color has action cards that reverse turn order, skip a player, or force the next player to draw two cards; in the latter case, if that next player also has a "draw two", then they can play it to force the player after them to draw four cards. Black cards can change the color of the top card, force players to pass all their cards in hand to the right, or do other things.

When you have only one card left in hand, you must say "One!" and if you don't and someone else catches you, you must draw two cards. Whoever plays all their cards first wins.

name: Super Plato
description:
A game for small children. Each player has a set of cards with different foodstuffs in front of them. Tiles with the same foodstuffs are in the center of the table, face down. There are two ways of playing:

Game 1 (3 and up): Players take turns flipping over a tile and asking "Who wants to eat... ?" The player who has the corresponding card shouts "I do" and flips over the card. On the other side of the card there is an activity that the player must perform. The first player who flips all their cards around is the winner.

Game 2 (5 and up): Players ask "Who feels like having ...?" and flip over a tile from the table. If it is the matching tile, they get to perform the action on the corresponding card. If not, they return it to the table and it's the next player's turn. The first player to perform all their actions, wins.

name: 20 sur 20
description:
In 20 sur 20, players use their five drawn number domino-like tiles to form sums of 20 on a line. Each sum of 20 scores one point. A completed sum of 20 is sealed with 20 token on the start and end of the sum and cannot be reused. However one of the number used by the sum can be reused by a crossing sum of twenty made by a player. If he can make another sum twenty with his hand the player can play again, then at the end of his turn he refills his hand to reach again the number of 5 tiles.

The game end with the use of all the tiles, the winner is a player with the most points.

—user summary

name: Bezzerwizzer Bricks: Tv-serier
description:
A small 60 card quiz game about television series.
Also has a category tile to make this an expansion for the big Bezzerwizzer games.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Bezzerwizzer Bricks: Berømte romancer
description:
A small 60 card quiz game about famous romances.
Also has a category tile to make this an expansion for the big Bezzerwizzer games.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Gangs of Rome: Sons of Orcus
description:
Devoted to the god of the Roman underworld, the Sons of Orcus haunt the Subura like spectres. Now you can add this terrifying trio to your Gangs of Rome experience.

With three finely sculpted white metal miniatures, cards and a selection of unique denarii, this Rome’s Most Wanted box set contains everything you need to unleash the Sons of Orcus on your foes.

This Sons of Orcus box set includes contains the following:

Three gang fighters
Three gang fighter cards
Three jigsaw bases
The Sons of Orcus coin plate containing four denarii
Four corresponding coin cards
Three Gangs of Rome D6 roman numeral die
The Mouth of Orcus terrain piece
A printed scenario and special rules

All miniatures are white metal and are supplied with the required MDF base for Gangs of Rome. May require assembly.
categories: Ancient, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Simulation, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Carl Spies
description:
This fast-paced game requires a keen eye, sharp mind, and even quicker reactions to win. In a wild "free-for-all", the first player to score 20 points wins by finding the people, places, and things depicted on the cards in their hand. However, players may thwart your efforts by playing action cards that keep you from earning points or to possibly help themselves when they’re losing.

Time spent playing CarlSpies will breeze by while also entertaining and challenging kids of all ages! Imagine that, so much fun without requiring the internet or a cell signal.

name: Pinball Showdown: Wizard Mode
description: Wizard Mode is an expansion for Pinball Showdown that adds new playfield devices, new combos, a fifth player, and variable wizard modes.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Video Game Theme

name: Monkey in the Middle
description: There’s only so many bananas to go around and you’re a hungry monkey! Players simultaneously play a monkey card pointing a finger or reveal a banana or coconut. If you end up with monkeys on your left and right pointing at you, your monkey card goes in the middle. If you reveal a banana, whoever is pointing at you can grab it! Same with coconuts except bananas are yummy and coconuts, well, they squash bananas! The player with the most bananas and the least cards in the middle wins. Includes variants for young children, older kids and adults.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Impulse Movement

name: The In-famous Coop War of Gutterman's Gulch
description:
The In-famous Coop War of Gutterman's Gulch is a mock war game in which both sides are trying to defeat each other by means of depleting their opponent's egg supply or trying to accumulate the majority of the nine hens into their coop.

Players will alternate six turns per round. Game play revolves attack and production cards. Attack cards cause an opponent to have their eggs, chicks or hens supply diminished. They can also send predators to attack them using the Special Ops cards. Egg laying and Upgrades allow you to expand your side's supplies and personnel.

Between both coops lies the Tufts. The Tufts are the area where the eggs roll from the coop and sit there till somebody is brave enough to send a chick down to retrieve them. Players send chicks down to guard the tufts and wait till they are "filled" and return them back to their egg supply.

A solo variant is included with the game. The In-famous Coop War of Gutterman's Gulch was an entry in the 2018 Mint Tin Contest.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Dust 1947: IJN Ninja Infiltration Squad
description:
Ninjas of the Imperial Japanese Navy are brutal troops who have been fighting for years for the glory of the Emperor and the Empire. They favor stealth and short range combat, where they can outmatch any opponent. When you see the Ninjas, it's often too late for your own good. Please note that this reference comes with an extra Unit Leader so you field two different looking squads.

This reference comes with two Dust 1947 unit cards, each with a different Unit Leader, for the IJN Bloc.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Snow Snow
description:
A cooperative game. Help the 4 friends cross the river before the sun melts the ice. Snowman do not move in one block, but part by part. A dot on the dice corresponds to one part of a snowman. The player must move first the head, then the middle, then the bottom of each snowman. First cooperative game to learn to play, win or lose together. The sun melts the iceberg. The player removes an iceberg of her or his choice from the board. The game ends when all the snowman have reached the opposite river bank. The game is lost if too many iceberg cards have been removed and the snowman cannot find a path across to the opposite bank.

—description from the designer

name: Remnants: Giant Scorpion Promo Card
description:
Shuffle the card to the other Badlands cards when setting up the game.
When you see this card, IMMEDIATELY begin rolling your dice to get 3 stars. The last player to show 3 stars on their dice injures 1 scavenger.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Real-time, Science Fiction
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Drakberget
description:
Drakberget is a card driven duel between two players, age 10 and up, where the goal is to capture the opponent's heir while protecting their own.

Players choose their movement secretly and perform them simultaneously.

—description from the publisher

name: The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin: Complete Edition
description:
The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin opens a whole new frontier for munchkins — the Wild West! Forget dragons and goblins — jackalopes and Davy Croc have just as much treasure to loot. Those plains may seem wide open, but there's lots of monsters to kill and lots of stuff to take.

Become a Cowboy with a Twenty-Gallon Hat, or an Indian on a Catamount. Fight Wild Bill Hiccup, the Killer Jalapeno, and a Barber Shop Quartet. Take The Annual Bath for an extra level. Or just pal around with your sidekick the Greenhorn, until you sacrifice him to distract a monster.

The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin: Complete Edition contains the original base game, all the cards from the Beating a Dead Horse expansion, each Western-themed promo card released, and thematic bookmarks that each contain a new rule for play.
categories: American West, Card Game, Fighting, Humor
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Butt Hurt
description:
Butt Hurt is a card game played among friends that reveals the, sometimes uncomfortable, truth. This game is not designed for sensitive people who get butt hurt easily. Man up and have fun! Butt Hurt game is not intended to be taken seriously.The first Reader reads a question card and privately votes for the person they think best matches question. Each player privately chooses who they think the Reader will choose. Each player that matches the Reader receives a point. Whichever player received the most votes gets to keep that card to read at the end of the game. Each person will take turns being the Reader, playing two rounds of red cards (BAD) & two rounds of blue cards (GOOD). The player with the most points at the end of the game wins. At the end of the game, each person reads the cards they have collected as their story. For example: I am out of shape and likely to steal your stuff, but I am the best motivational speaker who will always answer your call.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Trivia

name: トライアングル (TRIANGLE)
description:
User summary
トライアングル (Toraianguru) TRIANGLE is a co-operative card game where players try to release captured people of their kingdom. The game allows solitaire play.

In this game, there are 55 cards numbered 1-10, and the number on the card equals to the number of that card in the game. Of these 55 cards, the deck is shuffled and thirty-five cards are placed on the table. Players take turns playing cards from their hand to remove cards from the table.

Before the game starts, the players make a tableau of 35 cards, in overlapping skewed rows. Some are face up, some are face-down. (Place five of them in the first row. Then place next five cards in the second row, covering half of the previous row, sliding half of the card length rightward. Continue placing until the seventh row is made. By doing so, only the bottom (seventh) row is fully visible, and most of the cards are partially hidden by two cards of the next row.)

During your turn, you play a card from your hand to remove a fully visible card of the same value. Alternatively, you play two cards from your hand to remove a fully visible card whose value equals to the sum or difference of your two cards.

After you remove a card from the table, new cards can be fully visible. If there is a pair of fully visible cards of the same value, they are removed immediately. Continue this chain reaction until no pair is made.

When you can't remove any card by playing from your hand, you must spend a joker to remove any one card. All players lose the game if five jokers are spent and still you can't remove any card.

All players win the game when all cards are removed from the table.

Publisher's summary
Rescue the people trapped in the kingdom! A co-operative card game using a total of 55 cards, from one “1” card to ten “10” cards.

Each player in turn uses cards to make pairs with the cards in the center to remove them. The players are considered as the winners if all the cards in the center are removed. Although you may not talk about the numbers in your hand, you may form a strategy based on the number of cards of each type and aim for a win by communicating with your fellow players. It feels wonderful when you get a chain reaction!

Aim for a high score by using techniques such as adding/subtracting the numbers of two cards from your hand.

閉じ込められた王国の人々を救出しよう！　1が1枚～10が10枚計55枚のカードを使った協力カードゲーム。
順番にカードを出していき、場のカードとペアをつくって取り除いていきます。場のすべてのカードを取り除けたらプレイヤー全員の勝利。各自の手札の数字を言うのは禁止ですが、各カードの枚数をもとに作戦を立て、声をかけ合ってクリアを目指しましょう。上手く連鎖が決まったときの爽快感は格別です！　手札の2枚のカードの数字を足し引きして出すテクニックなども駆使して、高得点を目指そう！
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval, Number, Party Game, Puzzle
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Modular Board

name: Bezzerwizzer Bricks: Krimi
description:
A small 60 card quiz game about crime fiction.
Also has a category tile to make this an expansion for the big Bezzerwizzer games.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: PanzerBlitz: ACAV – Mechanized Warfare in Vietnam
description:
This game does not portray the jungle war in the boonies, but the regular war on the coastal plains. It is here that the war reached its final stages, and will eventually be won or lost ... The terrain involved is quite similar to a few patches south of Hue...

This game looks a lot like PanzerBlitz, and the maps line up, and the factors inter-relate pretty well. That is intentional. PzB is a good game, and more than that a good game system ... You can call this a variant of PzB if you wish. Or, see if PanzerGrenadiers would have done better than American Rangers in Vietnam.

—description from the publisher

ACAV consists primarily of a set of maps, unit counters (including Huey and Cobra helicopters), and scenarios along with some additional rules. Although described as if it were a stand-alone game, ACAV lacks any rules for movement and combat -- so it is actually an expansion module for PanzerBlitz.

The game was published in issue #2 of JagdPanther magazine which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Vietnam War, Wargame
publishers: (Web published), Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Dracomania
description:
The cards for this game were given with the purchase of some chips/crisp brands, namely Elma Chips (Portugal-Brasil), Mr. Snaki (Poland), Cheetos (Greece), and Dini (Serbia). Each bag contained a single card. It was produced by Degoes©, in 2008. Some of the cards have spot uv and some are foil. The simple game is played with a deck of 32 cards for both players, while the advanced game also includes the board. The game reminds of Top Trumps - you and your opponent must compare a single value that one of you chooses: magic, power, or fire, and he who has the greatest value wins the battle.

—user summary

name: Pug Time
description:
In Pug Time, players take on the role of pug owners. Each pug is different, but the goal for each pug is the same: achieve maximum happiness. To do this, players play cards that earn points in the three areas of pug happiness: eating, sleeping, and playing.

—description from the publisher

name: SMOOSH
description:
You start with two random categories, pick one example from each and SMOOSH them together. Say your two categories are Famous Rappers & Snack Foods... Some examples could be: Luda-crisps, Em & Ems, Skittle Jon, Pop-Corn-ye West. After everyone is finished creating and writing down their SMOOSH, the Smoodge (Smoosh + Judge) picks their favorite and the player that created it gets points and praise!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Strategic Command: World War 2
description:
Still in development

"Strategic Command: World War 2" is a strategic level wargame set in the European and Pacific theatres of the Second World War. It is a contest between three Factions; the Axis, the Western Allies and the Soviet Union. It is a game for 2-5 players and takes about 3-4 hours to play, for ages 12+.

The players are in control of all military, diplomatic and economic decisions for the major countries of each faction. Units represent army-level formations, entire air forces and fleets, so the focus is on the big picture.

Starting in Autumn 1939 and playing as far as the Summer of 1945, the players decide on how to use their forces and where to prioritise their efforts. Meaningful choices and consequences are a constant. How will the Second World War unfold?
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Star Flickers
description:
A modular sci-fi tabletop game of dexterity and space ships.

In Star Flickers, you assume the role of the captain of a light transport called a Starflicker. You will use your ship to outfly and outgun other pilots, capture enemy plans, win dangerous races and smuggle precious cargo. Winning depends on the rules of the game mode you have chosen to play.

Last Ship Flying! - Individual ships or teams of ships compete to devastate each other in battle.
Capture the Plans! - Two teams of Starflickers fight to capture their opponent’s plans and return it to their respective bases.
The Flicker Cup! - Individual ships race to be the first across the finish line while shooting each other with power-ups found on the course.
Twelve Parsecs! - Individual Starflickers compete around custom obstacle courses to see who can smuggle all of the cargo in the shortest number of turns.


—description from the publisher

name: Draughts for Three
description:
A NEW ANGLE ON AN OLD GAME:

A version of Draughts for three players designed and published by Artwood Games in South Australia.
The rules remain the same as draughts, and you can 'Crown' you pieces at either of your opponents ends. The board has a divided track so that half of each players pieces point down toward each opponent, which forces the game to be truly three player and prevents any form of ganging up.

name: Command Group Vietnam
description:
This games simulates tactical firefights during the Vietnam War. Special attention is paid to the command structure of the fighting troops. Players commanding several platoons (PLT), consisting of a command group (CG) and 3-4 squads (SQ) or 3-4 vehicles.

Players draw chits from a stack to activate a certain platoon formation. The CG of a formation can activate all of their subordinate units, which can perform actions. When all possible actions have been performed, the activation is completed and the next activation chit is drawn.

Through the bidding of command points (CP) it is possible to see the topmost activation chits and eventually change their position in the stack

When all the player’s PLT have been activated, a new turn starts. This goes on until the last round is reached, as indicated by the scenario and the winner can be determined according to the victory conditions.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Chit-Pull System, Hexagon Grid, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Kręgle Szachowe
description:
An apparently traditional game from Poland, where it is known as kręgle szachowe. No accepted English name has been found for it, but the words "kręgle szachowe" can be translated as "chess bowling" or "chess bowling pins".

Lech Pijanowski, a Polish games expert, described it as a “folk game” known in Germany and Scandinavia.

The game is played between two players (termed White and Black), who sit opposite each other across a 9×9 checkerboard, which has a line drawn around the central block of 3×3 squares. The source illustrates this board as having dark squares in each corner. Each player has nine undifferentiated pieces or stones. Initially, each player places one of his pieces in the corner square to his right, and the other eight complete a square with the first piece as its corner. White starts, and play is then alternate.

Pieces move a single space, to any of the (maximum of) four diagonally adjacent squares. Capturing is by custodianship, which is to say that an unbroken diagonal line of (one or more) enemy pieces, terminating with a friendly piece at one end of the line, will be captured if a second friendly piece is moved onto the space at the opposite end of the line. [The source is silent on whether such a move can capture lines of enemy pieces in more than one direction]. Unusually, though, captured pieces do not vacate the board, but are placed elsewhere on the board on a vacant space chosen by the captor, with the restriction that the new space must be the same colour as that from which it was removed. Thus, pieces will always remain on the same coloured square as that upon which they start the game.

The aim of the game is to complete a previously agreed arrangement of ones own pieces in the marked central sector of the board. Six examples of winning arrangements are:

–o– || ooo || ––o || ooo || ––o || o–o
ooo || o–o || ––o || ooo || –o– || –––
–o– || ooo || ooo || ooo || o–– || o–o
(where o represents a friendly piece, and – an empty square).
Arrangements involving more pieces are harder to achieve and will make for a longer game.

—user summary

name: Seeker
description:
A card game version of Guess Who? Each player spreads out an identical deck of 21 faces in front of them, and draws one card from the Character Cards to show who they are. They then take turns asking each other a yes/no question about the other's drawn face, and then they turn their all cards for whom the answer is "no" face down. The first player to guess the identity of the other player's drawn card wins.

With 2 copies, up to 4 may play together.

—user summary

name: Hemlock
description:
Hemlock is a strategic, medieval themed, card game.

In it, your goal is to manipulate an unfolding conspiracy to your advantage. Populate your King's court with high-valued figures, reduce the likelihood of their deaths, and minimize your opponents’ ability to do the same.

Hemlock features a play deck of 66 cards (11 cards per suit). Each card has a static or variable point value as well as an associated ability. When a player plays a card from their hand, they choose to play it for either points or for ability.

Hemlock is played over a series of rounds. At the beginning of each round, 2 cards are dealt face down to the center of the play area. These are the conspiracy cards. Actions played during the course of a round can change the conspiracy cards, but there are always, and only, 2 conspiracy cards in a given round.

Players take turns moving clockwise, playing 1 card per turn from their hand with the goal of accruing the highest round-point total. The player with most points at the end of a round earns the privilege of examining the 2 conspiracy cards and then assigning them to 2 different players' courts (score piles).

The number of cards in each player's court is known to all, but the value of the cards are kept secret even to their owner until a specified number of cards is present in a given court. When this number of cards is reached, the game ends. Players tally the value of the cards in their court (the ones that aren't poisoned by Hemlock!) and the player with the highest valued court wins.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Medieval, Political, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Trick-taking, Variable Player Powers

name: Aim for the Bullseye
description:
Statistical simulation game that allows the replay of professional darts tournaments from the 1970s through the 2000s.

Each historical player is presented with an Average Performance rating which is added to a roll of five 10-sided dice to determine who has the upper hand in the head to head match-up. Historical players also have a Tournament rating which can increase the number of dice rolled.

The higher total over three sets of rolls wins the leg, with each match being a best of 11 competition.

—user summary

name: Wild Guess Chase!
description:
The game has 72 letter cards and a 1-minute sand timer. With 4 or more players, teams of 2-3 players are recommended.

Each player (or team) is dealt 8 cards, and each player makes a word of 3 or more letters from their hand. (They may discard and draw 3 cards until they are able to make a word.)

In their turn, a player is the Word Hider, who lays out their word face down, turns the first letter face up, and starts the timer. Each other player shouts out guesses for the word. At any time before the timer runs out, if 2 or more players agree to see another letter, the Word Hider reveals another letter, and the guessing continues. Once a player correctly guesses the word, the Word Hider says "That's it" and reveals the word; the player who guessed it keeps all the cards that were hidden when the correct guess was made. If no correct guess is made, the Word Hider keeps all the letters of the word. Unclaimed cards are discarded, and Word Hider fills their hand back to 8 cards.

Players keep taking turns being the Word Hider until the deck runs out and no one can make a word from their hand. At that point, the player with the most cards won from guesses is the winner.

—user summary

name: När då då?: Berömda byggnadsverk
description:
A standalone expansion for När då då (The Best of Chronology) with cards containing trivia about famous buildings.

Gameplay is similar to the original game. On the players turn, an opponent draws a card from the deck and reads the text on the card. If the player successfully points out where the card should go in their current timeline, the card is added above the player Time lock and the player may then either decide to end the turn and move the cards above the time lock to the safety below it or try to get another card. If the player fails to place a card correctly, all cards gained in the current turn are lost, the turn ends and play passes to the next player.

The winner is the first player to win five cards.

When used with the original game, the cards from this game is added as another category. A new six-sided die and cardboard markers 1-6 are included to choose the category.

—user summary

name: EXO: Titans Unleashed
description:
This expansion includes:

4 EXO Titan miniatures,
4 themed game tiles,
16 EXO titan bug cards,
12 new exploration cards,
specific themed tokens,
4 new missions.


—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Crazy Cuts
description:
Can you cut out a picture of a frying pan that your team member will recognise?

This hysterical game really puts your creativity to the test as you snip, rip and shape a piece of paper into one of a host of challenging items.

—description from the box

name: Pigeonpocalypse
description:
Pigeonpocalypse is a fun and fast family card game for 2-6 players. It takes two minutes to learn and 20 minutes to play.

In this game, your armies of pigeon warriors, squirrel renegades and many others must fend off the violent grannies, dating couples and sleazy businessmen intruding on your precious park.

The winner is the player that best protects the park from the city slickers. You must strategically assign your defenders to the invaders, earning points by successfully defeating them. First to 15 points wins!

The game consists of a number of rounds. In each round new Visitors will arrive and the players will all get a chance to defeat them and earn their points. During the game you can use cards with special abilities to overcome the ods! Use a tornado to blow away an oponent from your targetted visitor. Exchange visitor for a new one from a deck to distract your oponent. Save powerfull minions after the round ends instead of discarding them, or peek into your oponents hand to plan your next move!

—description from the designer

name: みんなのお茶請け (Everyone's Served)
description:
みんなのお茶請け, which could be translated as "Everyone's Served" or "Tea Ceremony for All", is a game that features a lemur. What more do you need to know?

The game consists of 48 cards, numbered 1 to 48, worth a few positive points or a few negative points. Depending upon the player count, some amount of cards are dealt to each player; into a tableau; or to a deck near the tableau.

In turn, each player plays a card face up. Once each player has played a card, they are resolved in ascending order. The lowest card will earn that player any card in the tableau that is lower than it. Next, the second lowest card will earn that player any remaining cards lower than that player's card. This continues until the highest ranked card played takes any remaining cards. The cards taken are placed face down in a pile and that pile will constitute that player's score at the end of the game.

The cards played in one round become the tableau for the next round. Play continues until the players are out of cards. There are also 1 or 2 special "tea" cards (depending upon player count); these come into play during the last round and are used to distribute the cards played in the last round.

name: Fazi-Mühle
description:
The 2 players take turns placing their pieces on the board, attempting to make a line of 3. Once all the pieces have been placed, players may slide them. Whenever a player makes a line of 3, they remove an opponent's piece of his choice. When one player has only 3 pieces left, he may move any piece from any point on the board to any other point. As soon as one player is left with only two pieces, his opponent wins.

The game includes 3 double-sided game boards.

—user summary

name: Indiana Jones et les trésors perdus
description:
The game is a racing game with tricky cards such as 1000 Bornes.

As in the latter, you can pose pitfalls to the opponents: tiger, mygale, snake.

The course game is classic and the race has two stages:
to discover what treasure to look for;
to prevent enemy treasure seekers from doing this before his own.

—user summary

name: Macau Wars
description:
Macau-Wars Variation

Macau Wars It’s a major game variation of the Macau card game based on the Macau (card game) Macau Plawno Variation, still being in development on github.

Gameplay

2 or more players are dealt 5 cards each; after that, the top card from the deck is then placed on the table. Play starts to the dealer's right.

The next card played must be of the same suit or the same value as the card on the table. For example, If a 7 of spades was on the table, the player can play a 9 of spades or a 7 of clubs or any other card that matches 7 or spades. If the player cannot play a card, he must draw from the deck.

Cards cannot be played in runs, i.e. 5 of Spades, 6 of Spades, 7 of Spades, 7 of Hearts, 8 of Hearts, 8 of Clubs, 7 of Clubs but a minimum of two or more the same value cards can be played.

When an action card is played, the player next (or previous depend on the action card) in the sequence must complete the action or add to it to pass it onto the next player in sequence. When down to a single card, a player must say "Macau!". If a player forgets to call "Macau" before the next players move, the player must draw 5 cards. The winner of the game is the first player to have no cards; in instances of more than 2 players, gameplay continues until only one player is left with cards. In case of Macau Championships once the first player to have no cards wins and the game stops. The winner shuffles the cards and the new game starts. One point is then assigned to the winner.

For the avoidance of doubt: If the player plays King of Spades and King of Hearts with King of Hearts on top the next player will pick up 5 cards as the top card takes precedence in this case.

War

In this game, a scenario called a war and deception can be created when players consecutively play 'special cards' to make other players increase their card count.

War is started when 2, 3, King of Spades (to a previous player) or King of Hearts is played. Causing players to pick up cards. When a war starts, players can play any 2s and 3s as the suit and value are being ignored during the war. Players can also play King of Spades and King of Hearts regardless of the suit currently on the deck and value of the cards as long as they are 2, 3 or mentioned Kings. Queen of Hearts can be played anytime during the war to stop the war causing the player to not pick up any cards. In this variation of the game, players can often pick up as many as 20 cards (they all add up, e.g. 2+3+2+King of Spades+King of Heart=17).

When King of Spades is played the previous player must pick up 5 cards or play another action card (any 2, 3, King of Hearts, King of Spades (to a previous player)). After the previous player, the game goes back to the player who played King of Spades.

Any queen can be placed at any time on any war card regardless of the current suit. See below section for the action of each Queen.

Action Cards

2, 3, King of Spades, King of Hearts - War cards that cause players to pick up cards (2,3,5 respectively).

If a Jack or Ace is played, the player placing the Jack or Ace can call for a non-action card value (in case of Jack) or a suit (in case of Ace). The difference is that the suit is ignored and any Jack can be placed on any Ace, and any Ace can be placed on any Jack, therefore, ignoring the requested suit or value of the previous player.

Queen of hearts - stops the war and causes the player not to pick up any cards.

Queen of diamonds - the next person is skipped (also during the war).

Queen of spades - order of play switches directions (also during the war).

Queen of clubs - player can chose who play next (cannot chose her/himself) (also during the war).

If a 4 is played the deception part starts, and all the players must miss a go, unless they have a 4 (if they don't have a 4 or they chose not to play the 4, they don't pick a card from the deck), in which case they can add this to the original 4, and all players in sequence must miss a go, unless someone has a 4, in which case they can add this to the original 4 and so on. If no one else has a 4 then the last player, who put 4 plays as many times as there are 4s. For example, if there are four 4s after the last player played the 4, the player must play four times. Note: the last player will play four times against him/herself, that also include all the action cards which will apply to the player him/herself. The deception is when someone doesn't want to play a 4 but has it and can play a 4 after everyone said they don't/have a 4 causing this player to have more turns.

Joker replaces any card.

Open Cards

The more difficult version of Macau Wars (and any Macau variation) is a game played with open cards. That means that all the players cards and the draw deck is shown. This is similar to Chess where by knowing all the cards players must think about strategy and future moves. Open cards variation might take hours to finish.

name: Escape from Evil Manhattan
description:
For some reason you find yourself in Evil Manhattan, about to be attacked by a bunch of assassins. Luckily the assassins run through the streets in a relatively predictable way - can you alter their route so you can escape alive?

Each round starts by laying out the city streets as a grid of cards and placing assassins at the top and players at the bottom. City cards have the same street layout on the front and back, but the front (face-down at the start) has weapons that can make assassins more dangerous. After the city and assassins are laid out, each player decides what part of their body to protect. Then each player in turn can place blocking tokens to block off streets. After that the players can choose which weapon to defend against, and then the cards that aren't blocked are flipped over and the assassins go to work!

The assassins follow the streets towards the players, but take a turn whenever possible, following the rules of the Japanese "amida kuji" lottery system. When an assassin reaches a player, damage is calculated based on the weapons the assassin picked up, their preferences, and what the player chose to block. Repeat this for three rounds and - if anyone survived that long - the player with the least damage is the winner!

—user summary

name: Magilogical: A Here be Dragons Game
description:
Magilogical is an epic battle between Wizards and Dragons for supremacy over the Mythical Land of Ict. By using spells based on the rules of Logic you must defeat your opponents and emerge victorious.

Magilogical is a trick-taking game reminiscent of the classic card game War, with a couple of twists. You have a choice of multiple (six) scores to choose one or two from, and there is an additional component of logic gates (AND, XOR, etc.) that make it so that you don't always want the higher value.

—user summary

name: Madrid, qué bien resistes
description:
This is solitary, easy and short card driven game for the Battle of Madrid (november-december 1936) of the Spanish Civil War.

There are two types of Cards. Battle Cards with a numerical value from 1 to 7, and Position Cards, which represent historical fortifications.

The player must set up his battle cards in the gaps before you draw all the fortification cards. when a Positioin card is draw, you can't place any more cards in this gap.

Victory or defeat for the player is when all cards are drawn. If all gaps (12) have a Position card, is a republican Victory, but if there is any gap with 7 or 14-28 Battle cards without Position, there is a Fascist victory.

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Humpalump
description:
Humphrey the Humpalump has lost his legs. To help him find his legs, players have to roll the ball along his back. If they all lands on an empty slot you can add one of your legs. The first player to get all their legs on Humphrey wins the game. Humpalump, the fast fun game for all ages!

—user summary

name: 大宇宙すごろく (Cosmic Sugoroku)
description:
Introduction:
The compassionate bodhisattva has made a decree, seeing who can blast across the universe and reach enlightenment the fastest! Sugoroku is a classic game of moving pieces according to the roll of the dice, but dice won’t be needed in this cosmic high-speed sugoroku race game!

Gameplay summary:
Players try to be the first to move from the start space to the finish space. In each round, players simultaneously show one card from their hand indicating the number of spaces they wish to move. If their played card is unique, then they move; otherwise, they do not. All played cards are passed clockwise, and players in last will then sacrifice a card from their hand to make a small movement.

JP Introduction:
時には菩薩の慈悲をも駆使し、大宇宙を駆け巡り、誰よりも速く憶千万年の概念に到達せよ！ このゲームはサイコロを使わない、すごろく音速大宇宙レースゲーム！

name: ROKU
description:
This is a captivating game based on quick reaction and attention where everything revolves around number six. Instantly count colors on cards, seize cards of other players, roll the dice most accurately! Get the biggest score you can and become the best in this colorful folly!

ROKU is an easy to master game for all kinds of players!

—description from the publisher
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Dice, Number, Party Game

name: Eat It, Drink It, Smoke It, Do It
description:
The game comes with a playing board and 200 cards, each with an item on one side. On her turn, a player guesses whether the item is for eating, drinking, smoking, or doing. The other side of the card indicates the number of spaces that the player moves her piece for the answer that she gave. Some items will have multiple possible answers, with different distances to move for each answer. Players take turns until someone reaches the finish line on the board.

—user summary
categories: Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Trivia

name: Flip Words
description: Flip Words is a two-player game that is played on a crossword grid, much like Scrabble. One player uses the yellow side of the tiles; the other player uses the white side. Players take turns adding words to the board in Scrabble fashion. Whenever the active player adds to an opponent's word, the active player flips the tiles in that word to his color. When all the tiles have been played, the player with the most tiles on the board in his color wins.
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Hand Management, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Unico
description:
Unico is a game with 66 cards, based on the traditional game Crazy eights.

Everyone gets 5 cards and must play a matching card (colour or animal/number): if they haven't a matching card, pick up 1 from the stock pile.
In the basic version there the following special cards:

chameleon: you can play it when you want, like a joker.
crab: play clockwise/counter-clockwise order.
kangaroo: the next player misses his turn.


In the advanced version, there also these special cards:

snake: you can exchange one card with another player.
hands: all player put their hand on this card. The last player draws 2 cards.


The first player to discard all their cards wins.

—description from the publisher

name: Identiquest
description:
The Great Gemstone Exhibition of 1978 stirs the greed of the biggest thieves in the region.
To win the biggest booty, you will have to be discreet because the other thieves will try to unmask you and denounce you to the authorities.


Look at your secret identity and the color gems you have to steal.
Take the cards with the most of your gems color that match your character.
look at what do the others take and identify their secret character. Then report them to the police...
Take as many gems as possible to become the richest but remain discreet not to compromise your secret identity!


—user summary

name: Fashion
description:
A card game played with a standard deck, designed by Mason Yeater. Using elements of area control games, this simple card game has players competing for scoring areas which range from 1 to 12 using a series of card in their hand.

Players simply lay cards over different scoring areas, and when all cards have been placed the topmost card scores the area. The game is designed to be played over several rounds.

Scoring areas are represented by Jacks, Queens and Kings in all different suits. Players cards range from ace to 10. Players can only play a card that is higher than the previous one played onto a scoring area. An ace, however, resets the area: it can be played onto any card, but any card can be played onto an ace.

The game plays for between 2 to 4 people, with a team-based variant for 4 players.

—user summary

name: Cards Against Colonialism
description:
"A Party Game For Indigenant Peoples"

We are stronger when we laugh. This game confronts difficult issues and helps raise discussions. Humor makes it easier to talk about difficult issues. CAC attempts to embrace the modern Native Culture, and allows us to learn and laugh at the same time.

The eldest player starts as the Emcee and draws a red card. He or she reads aloud the question or fill-in-the-blank phrase on the red card. Everyone, including the Emcee, holds ten white cards, and answers the question or fills in the blank(s) by passing one (or two) white cards face down, to the Emcee.

The Emcee shuffles all of the answers and shares each card combination with the group. After all the card combinations are read, every player votes on their favorite response by placing their token on that white card. The player who submitted the card with the most tokens wins that round and keeps the red card. After the round, everyone draws back up to ten white cards, and the duties of the Emcee pass to the person on the left. The player who is first to collect five red cards is declared the Token Indin'.

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Political

name: Guild of Dice
description:
The Story
Morland is an island of swords and magic. There are monsters hiding in the forest, thieves are ruling the mountains, and at night, the undead crawl onto the streets. If you take a single step outside the town, danger will lurk all around you. People called them Adventurers who challenges their own wisdom and courage against the dangerous world.

You are the guild master of a group of adventurers. Success is yours, if you can make your guild's name known throughout Morland. To grow your reputation, you need to show your people courage and fame.

The dice is thrown! Let the adventure begin!

Game Description
As a guild master, players will send their adventurers to quests. Adventurers are represented by worker tokens and are placed in areas indicated by 1-12, based on the dice roll. Compete with other players on the majority of each quest and earn resources such as money and bravery. Use your resources to gain fame, or hire backers to manipulate dice and workers.


Roll three dice, change the die if possible.
Plan how to distribute the dice.
Place the workers on quests according to the plan.
Compete the majority in each quests and earn resources!


The number of points multiplied by courage and fame is the final victory point. By planning the dice, control the randomness of the roll, and with the help of the backers, bring your own guild to glory!

—user summary

ストーリー
モーランド――それは剣と魔法の島。森には魔獣が潜み、山には盗賊がのさばり、夜になればアンデッドが街道を徘徊します。町の外に一歩でも足を踏み出せば、そこは危険と隣り合わせの世界。そんな世界に自らの知恵と勇気をもって挑む者を冒険者と民衆は呼びました。

あなたは、そんな冒険者たちを擁する冒険者ギルドの主、すなわちギルドマスターです。あなたのギルドの名をモーランド中に知れ渡らせることができれば、あなたの立身出世は思いのままとなることでしょう。そのためには勇敢さと名声を民衆に示す必要があります。

さぁ、賽は投げられました。モーランドの覇権を手に入れるための冒険を始めましょう！

ゲーム概要
プレイヤーはギルドマスターとして、配下の冒険者をクエストに派遣します。冒険者はワーカー駒で示され、それらをダイスロールによってもたらされる１～１２のエリアに配置します。他のプレイヤーとワーカー駒のマジョリティを競いながら、お金（ゴールド）と勇敢さ（バロー）で示されるリソースを獲得します。獲得したリソースを元に名声（フェイム）を得たり、ダイスやワーカーを操作したりする後援者を味方につけましょう。


3個のダイスを振り、出目を確定させる。
出目が確定したダイスを、どのように配置するか計画する。
計画に従ってワーカーを配置。
エリアごとにマジョリティを競い、リソースを獲得！


勇敢さ（バロー）と名声（フェイム）を掛け合わせた数が勝利点となります。ダイスロールによる不確定な運要素を計画によってコントロールし、後援者の力を借りながら、自らの運営するギルドを栄光へと導きましょう。

—ユーザーサマリー
publishers: メリーアンドリューワークス(merry-andrew-works)

name: Game of the Elections
description:
A really simple and fun board game based on the greek elections of 1989. It can be played from 2 to 5 players. Each player takes the pawn of a political leader and his goal is to be the first player who reaches the endpoint (number 100), and become the new prime minister of Greece.
There are many spots/numbers on the board, whιch when you reach them you can go forward or backwards, lose your turn or be eliminated of the game.

—user summary

name: Don't Be SHY!
description:
This is a communication card game to talk about their own life and philosophy.
Each player send a card in hands that written question about life.
Answer question each other, repeat this 10 times.
At the end of this game, all players will understand each other about thier lives.
This game provides the opportunity to respect the other people's live.

▼Concept
Talk myself frankly, and understand each other.
I want to provide these opportunities. So I produced this game.

This game includes elements of self-development. But I hope you enjoy easily.
At first time, parhaps you will feel you don't want to speak about yourself deeply. But I hope you will find pleasure that to speak your self and to know other people and share lifes.

▼Overview
Let's talk about yourself! And let's get to know friends better!
A person who talks a lot wins.
This is a card game to help you communicate and mutual understanding.

Question Cards Ex.

What was the best experience in your life?
When was the most excited moment in your life?
What was the most accomplishment thing in your life?
What is the ideal work for you?
What ideal person do you want to become in your future?
What is the part that you most love about yourself?
What is the worst regrettable thing in your life?
When did you consider suicide?
What was the worst crisis that might have ruined your life?


—description from the designer

Players take turns answering questions. If a player answers a question, he gains one point. If he does not answer a question, another player may answer an gain the point. The player with the most points wins the game.

—user summary

name: As Majesty
description: The game As Majesty is a chess-like game played between two contenders, moving pieces over an hexagonal field where the objective is to invade the territory of the other player.

name: My Rotten World
description:
An adult party card game that celebrates the rotten world. It's funny, totally different and politically INcorrect.

My Rotten World is an adult party game where you steal, dump, peek, barf cards to win the ultimate title of the Rotten Dragon. Our humorous illustrations bring the cards to life.
To win, you must get rid of all of your cards, while holding on to the Rotten card. This proves you are the most rotten of them all!

Setup
This game is for 2-4 players, ages "18" and over.
Every player is dealt with five cards. The rest of the deck is placed face down. Keep space next to the deck for the discard pile.

How do you play?
The most rotten person starts the game and the gameplay follows a clockwise direction.
For your turn, you can play any card in your hand by putting it in the discard pile. You take the action that is on the card. If you don't have a card that you want to play, then you draw from the deck as your turn.

When you start the game, the rotten card can only be one of 3 places. In your hand, in someone else’s hand or in the deck. During your turn, you will play a card in your hand and do that action. So if you think that one of your friends has "the rotten card"? You can “steal” a card or “swap hands”. If you think that the card is in the deck? You can play “Grab Four, you whore!” and take 4 from the deck in hopes of pulling the rotten card.
What if you have the rotten card? It’s time to try to get rid of all of the other cards.
Maybe play a “dump” card and give your shit to someone else. Oh and remember, if you have the rotten card, it’s best to keep a poker face

How do you win?
You WIN when the only card you have left is the ROTTEN card.

To get the ROTTEN card: you will steal cards, draw cards, swap cards, grab cards, dump cards, burn cards and do whatever it takes to get….and keep the ROTTEN card.

—description from the publisher
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Case #02
description:
A dead body was found on a rainy night.
You have to reconstruct the crime to find out the murderer, and prevent further tragedies.

Case #02 is co-operative real-time deduction card game. Players need to exchange alibi cards for more clues. And have to find out the culprit who has no alibi. Players will take points if they successfully determined the culprit before any victims are killed.

This murder-themed game is a game of looking for two true criminals out of nine suspects in a limited time of three minutes. The hint for the perpetrator is limited to the number of the investigators, and not only the time but also the new victims (the people who thought they were suspects are killed by the criminals!) As the reasoning is delayed. It does not matter if you resolve the case beyond three minutes, but the only thing left is the wound.
And the opportunity to point out the killer is only once per game, regardless of the number of players and who is calling it! If this is a single chance, and you can not match the truth, then everyone will be defeated.

name: Mauern Babylon
description:
Wooden made abstract game. Players start in their corner area of an 8x8 grid with their hut and 3 square pieces around it. In your turn, you place either an adjacent square piece or you put it onto another square piece (of an opponent as well) if it is adjacent to you. When all pieces are built, the player or team with the most spaces controlling (including empty ones that are only adjacent to him and maybe the border) wins.
The advanced version introduces male and female meeples and for each player another 2 huts. If you place a piece onto another, you may add a meeple and put it in your hut or you can move one in front of your hut. Alternatively, you may move one ore more of your meeples on the same piece anywhere but only changing once the height by one step. You may fight another meeples of the same sex by throw of a die and you may marry one of the opposite sex and found a new hut. In the end, you multiply the controlled spaces by the number of your huts and add one point for each unmarried meeple of your own.

—user summary

name: Royal Gardeners
description:
The Queen requires a new gardener. She will assign a small portion of her royal garden to each candidate to decorate them with her favorite flowers. The gardener who manages to please her majesty with most beautiful flower arrangements, will become Queen's new royal gardener!

Royal Gardeners game is designed for 2 to 5 players, ages 7 and up, with games lasting about 15-25 minutes.

Each player will get one portion of Queen's garden with certain number of spaces. On each of those spaces, players may plant flowers of 6 different colors. Players will also collect cards that represents different goals, each providing certain amount of victory points. At the end of the game, player with most victory points is the winner of the game.

Each turn, a player may choose either to plant flowers or pick a goal card from the middle of the table. When planting flowers, player must choose 2 different colors of any kind, and then, him and all other players, must plant those flowers in their portion of the garden. Flowers must be planted next to each other so it will not be possible to make a perfect arrangement of colors in the garden.

The tactics and the decision that players have to make on their turn is: weather to plant colors they need, in order to fulfill the goal cards, or to skip planting in order to take another goal card that can potentially bring him more victory points at the end of the game.

—description from the designer

name: World of Snooker
description:
A statistical simulation game by Roberto Chiavini focusing on the Snooker World Championships. Initial releases allow replaying of the 1927-30 championships, or the 1977-80 championships.

Every player in the competition is rated with an Effectiveness value (representing points scored through the tournament) and a Tournament rating (representing how far the player advanced, and providing the opportunity for bonus dice each round.)

Each frame players tests their Tournament rating, then throw a number of 10-sided dice based on that result. The total showing on the dice is added to the Effectiveness value and the higher total wins the frame.

name: Fault!
description:
In Fault!, you are one of several startup companies in a dangerously misguided competition to determine who gains the exclusive mineral rights to the famously rich Tremor Gulch mine. To impress the judges, you'll gather gems to complete contracts for points and powers, and you'll vie over achievements which transform into trophies.

By hiring the right combinations of miners and backing them with carefully managed resources and planning, you're certain to undermine your competition. But be careful - if you mine too aggressively, you'll earn fault from the supervisors, which carries steep fines now or deeper penalties if ignored. And if you or your competitors mine too greedily, the reinforcements in the mine will start to break - when a mine tile loses its last reinforcement, it caves in, taking miners with it.

Combining resource management and efficiency planning with direct player interaction, Fault! is a truly unique hybrid of gaming styles. Whether you're skillfully navigating the maze of the mine to excavate carefully selected stones or wildly flinging dynamite and grabbing every exploded element, you're sure to unearth stories to remember.

—description from the publisher
categories: Exploration, Fantasy, Industry / Manufacturing, Maze, Territory Building
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Yummy Restaurant
description:
The annual Super chef-contest to begin soon, chef country have to try it, in order to meet more guests, they stir the pot Britain versatile demonstrated most vividly.

Of course, to get the most gold per year restaurant chef, you will get "super chef" of the title. Kitchen King Tournament will begin, come to show your cooking it!

The last player who recently cooked a meal starts. Gameplay is clockwise. Steps are as follows:

Draw 4 order cards and ﬂip them over, line them up in front of you.
Toss your frying pan three times.  After every toss,the food tokens that ﬂip right side up can be put onto any of your plates on the work table.
After three tosses, all plates that match the order cards earn you gold coins from the bank.



Discard all used order cards into discard pile. It’s the end of your turn. Pass the pan and all food tokens to next player.


When all of the cards run out,the game is over. The player who wins most coins wins the title,“King of the Forest Chef.”

—user summary

name: 名人伝 (The Legend of the Greatest Master)
description:
In 名人伝, also known as The Legend of the Greatest Master, 3-4 players are training in archery skills. It is a trick-taking game with 5 suits, each with 7 cards, and staggered values (e.g. 0-6, 1-7, 2-8.) There is also one card showing a bow and arrow that serves as the start player marker.

Players must follow suit, and each trick has two winners. The player that played the highest valued card overall will collect the cards, but does not become the start player for the next trick; rather, this honor goes to the player who played the highest valued card in the lead suit.

Players sort the cards they have won into piles by suit, always keeping the lowest value card collected in each suit on the top. At the end of a hand, players are ranked and receive a number of points based upon this ranking. The first criteria is collecting the most suits, and the second is having the highest sum among the lowest cards collected in those suits. Additionally, the player who holds the start player card at the end of a hand is ineligible to score.

The game lasts a number of rounds equal to the number of players and the high score wins.

name: ムラオサ (Muraosa)
description:
ムラオサ (Muraosa) is a game that develops the village by becoming Osa of the village of Jomon period. Osa travels for the village, acquires various resources, and develops new technologies.

First, decide the destination. As Osa can only walk towards the destination, he needs to think and decide enough.
Next step will of course walk. In the middle of the market, we will acquire various resources and pay new resources.
Once you get to the destination, it's a score. Depending on the distance from your village, the higher you get the better score. After that, we return to the village, decide a new destination, and the next journey begins.

The map is made by combining nine boards. This combination requires a different strategy each time. In addition, because the action that can be done varies depending on the location of the village, you have to think of the strategy under the conditions different from other players. This asymmetry is also one of the features.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Roman Rummy
description:
This high-tension 2-player card game takes classic rummy games to an exciting new level. A 54-card deck includes five suits with 10 cards each, plus four special "Caesar" cards which create a plethora of decisions for clever players.

The suits are a representation of ancient Rome at its zenith: Wine, Bread, Games, Legions and Gold.

As in standard rummy, players start with a hand of cards and alternately draw from a face down deck. They can meld sets, and also meld runs in the same suit. They also discard a card from their hands at the end of their turn. As in 500 Rummy, the discards are overlapped and any number of cards can be taken from the pile instead of from the draw deck.

However, things are not so simple. For example, if Caesar debases the currency, any gold cards that have been melded are removed from play. This will prevent every 3-card meld with a gold card from scoring.

The other three Caesar cards require additional interesting thought-processes throughout each round of play -- and there is no telling which will appear, or when!

The first player to reach 100 points wins!

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play

name: Zero Kelvin: A Freezing Dice Game
description:
A roll and write played in three rounds of five challenges using dice. Using the push your luck and dice freeze mechanisms this game plays solo or with others. In the solo game set your target score based on your most comfortable/preferable temperature (some like it warm like at the beach; others like it brisk like in the mountains). Try to beat your target temperature starting from 0 degrees Kelvin! The multiplayer version includes following other player's rolls. Each challenge has some form of luck mitigation including earning re-rolls. Zero Kelvin is a free print-and-play available in the files section below.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck

name: Fawlty Towers
description:
This simple game aims to blend tactical choices with dexterity, and requires you to balance the risk of stacking cubes on the tallest tower against the reward of getting the highest valued cards on the table.

4 columns of cards are laid out on the table. Players get cards by stacking cubes on any one of 4 towers. In order to get for instance the third card in a column, you have to place a cube of the same colour as the card on top of a tower that contains at least the cubes to match the colours of the cards in the two first spaces. If the tower falls, you get nothing.

Score points based on the values of the cards, and the sets of similar symbols that your are able to collect.

—description from the designer

name: All Your Base
description:
This game is developed to be played with the Green Box of Games game system.

In AD 2101, war was beginning… Build up your base and install the correct hardware and software on your defence stations to prepare for the oncoming attack. In this game for up to 6 players you play cards from your hand to perform one of three actions, and pass the cards you don’t need to the next player.

With each card you may either:

Use the symbol to buy a defence station (tile) with the same symbol
Use the colour to buy hardware (cube) with the same colour to place on any of your stations
Play the card itself as software onto a station with the same symbol


You score points for the value of the cards installed as software, and you score for the cubes if they match the colour of the card.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Ascension of the Galaxy
description:
Ascension of the Galaxy is the rich, maneuver-based spaceship combat game where thinking ahead is not an option. Plenty of decisions have to be made every turn.

Although this is a print-and-play game, you could easily use your own space mat with a hex-grid and miniatures to use making for a beautiful gaming experience.

Think Ahead ... or Perish!

Command in AotG takes more thought than considering what target to shoot at. Players must think of such variables as:


"What shield is facing my opponent after we move?"
"My ship can't power everything - what systems are essential this turn?"
"My ship is getting beat up. Should I start charging the hyperdrive now?"
"I want my ship over there, but will turning the ship now put me at an extreme disadvantage next turn?"


A Maneuver-Based Game

The ships in AotG do not turn on a dime (with one exception). When ships turn, they are committed to moving forward a distance before they can turn again.

Players look for ways to take advantage of this because not only are ships weaker from the rear, ships also cannot fire behind them (with one exception).

Unique Ships = Unique Tactics

One of the key strengths of Ascension of the Galaxy is that each of the six races are vastly different from one another. Not just with weapons and armor, but how they power systems, take damage, and even how they enter hyperspace. Each race feels truly alien making for interesting tactics and gameplay.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game, Variable Player Powers

name: The Kazakh Khanate
description: The Kazakh Khanate (Qazaq Khanate) is a competitive game for 2-4 players where each player tries to unite a certain number of the Kazakh clans under one banner the fastest. Players take turns moving around the board claiming clans or battling for their support.

name: Bad Medicine: The Unsafe Expansion
description: A small booster that adds additional NSFW cards to Bad Medicine.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: An Age of Sword & Arrow
description:
An Age of Sword & Arrow is a set of miniatures wargame rules for the ancient and medieval periods with an educational intent: the writers hope it will inspire students to learn about military history.

The game features DBX-style stands grouped into "companies", which are the basic manoeuvre units of the game. Troops are classed by role (close combat or range), mobility (light, medium, or heavy), and type (infantry of cavalry), and rated for efficiency for various kinds of combat, and possibly further differentiated by various special rules. Combat resolution is through buckets of dice - the attacker rolls to hit, and the defender to save.

Army lists range from the Late Bronze Age to the Norman Conquest of England.

name: Third Strongest Mole
description:
３番目に強いもぐら, roughly translated as Third Strongest Mole, is a 5-player only trick-taking game with one suit. The game consists of 37 cards, ranked 1 to 37, and 3 front and back rule cards, printed on 4 sheets of perforated business card stock.

All but 2 cards are dealt to the players, and the remaining 2 cards are set aside face up, with one designated for the 1st place player and one for the 5th place player.

After each person has played a card to a trick, points are awarded based upon rank, with the player who played the highest card earning 2 points, the 2nd highest 1 point, the 3rd highest 0 points, etc. The 1st place player then takes the set aside card into their hand and returns another to the table. The 5th place player does the same.
